Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Capturing People's Expectations of Privacy with Mobile Apps by Combining Automated Scanning and Crowdsourcing Techniques

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of our work is to (a) capture people's expectations and surprises in using mobile apps in a scalable manner, and to (b) summarize these perceptions in a simple format to help people make better trust decisions. Our main idea is analyzing privacy in the form of people's expectations about what an app will and won't do, focusing on where an app breaks people's expectations. We are building an App Scanner that combines automated scanning techniques with crowdsourcing. Automated scanning captures the behavior of an app, while crowdsourcing is used to interpret how expected and acceptable this behavior is. This information is used as the basis for building a better privacy summary for apps. We have organized an interdisciplinary team with expertise in mobile computing, computer security, systems, and human-computer interaction.

Success in this work will include results in: (a) the design and implementation of an App Scanner that combines automated techniques with crowdsourcing techniques for analyzing and interpreting privacy-related behaviors of mobile apps; (b) a series of evaluations of this app scanner, showing effectiveness, accuracy, and scalability; (c) the design and evaluation of better privacy summaries, which prioritize and highlight the most unexpected behaviors of an app; and (d) demonstration of a new conceptualization of privacy, namely privacy as expectations. Success will also help end-users, corporate and government employees manage their privacy better than can be done today.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project is to improve smartphone app privacy, by (a) developing new app analysis techniques to find unusual behaviors, (b) combining those results with crowdsourcing, and (c) offering simple user interfaces that can convey those behaviors to interested stakeholders.

Our main results are at the web site PrivacyGrade.org, which presents the results of our analysis on over a million Android apps. Apps are graded using a crowdsourced model based on people's expectations. For example, most people don't expect a motorcycling game to use the smartphone's microphone, and if it does, we consider that to be a large privacy problem. In contrast, it's fairly obvious that Google Maps uses location data, and so we consider that to be a small privacy problem.

Using this idea, we crowdsourced a large number of responses of people's expectations about app behaviors, and aggregated the results to build a model of people's expectations. A simple example is that people are very uncomfortable with apps using the microphone for advertising, but are fairly neutral about apps that use location data for social networking.

We then applied this model to over a million Android apps. We downloaded free apps from Google Play, analyzed what data they use and for what purpose, and then applied our crowdsourced model to understand how concerned people would likely be. We summarize the results as a grade of A+, A, B, C, or D.

Overall, our work on PrivacyGrade.org has had positive impact. We have shared our data with the Federal Trade Commission, Google, and other researchers. The FTC has also used early results from this work to help fine egregious apps that were collecting a great deal of information about users without their knowledge. Some app developers have also informed us that they have changed their behaviors in response to our work. Lastly, our work has been featured in a number of popular press venues, including CNN, NY Times, Slate, CBS, BBC, and more.

From a scientific perspective, our work has also led to new ways of evaluating privacy for apps, and ways of scaling up the analysis for millions of apps.  Our work also helped lead to new ways of using crowdsourcing to improve privacy and security.
